Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Collaborative Research: Leading Edge Vortex Evolution on Compliant Biologically-Inspired Wings

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511507(Willis) and 1510962(Jones)

This is a collaborative proposal that will utilize experiments and computations to investigate the flow field generated around a flexible wing. While a lot of research has been done to understand how lift forces are generated around solid wings, it is important to also understand why and how soft, flexible wings are used to generate lift. Fundamental knowledge generated through this work can impact both biological sciences as well as the autonomous drone industries (commercial and military).

A lot of prior research work has been done on rigid wings, showing that wing kinematics can alter the strength and position of the shear layer that feeds the so-called leading edge vortices (LEVs) that are responsible for the bulk of the lift forces. The vortex dynamics have been shown to result in fluid dynamic forces. More recently, LEVs have been observed on moderate Reynolds number, and in morphing and compliant wings during low speed flight and maneuvering of insects. The proposed project will advance this area of research by investigating wing compliance effects, by examining the vortices generated at the leading edge at moderate Reynolds numbers (where the LEV is a significant but not necessarily dominant source of lift) and by quantifying importance of wing compliance and vortex dynamics to lift force production. Furthermore, educational activities are proposed via integration of research results into university courses as well as the development of several instructional materials for local K-12 schools in both Massachusetts and Maryland.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological flyers use their lightweight wings to generate flight forces, and as a result, these wings respond by bending, flexing and deforming. Bird and bat wing skeletal structures also promote wing rotation around the front or leading edge of the wing. Previous research has shown that smaller sized biological flyers exploit a flow structure called a leading edge vortex (LEV) to increase arodynamics force production. An LEV is a rotating flow -- similar to an eddy that forms and follows behind a swimmer's hand moving through water. For a wing, the LEV forms on the upper (i.e., low pressure) surface of a wing.

 

This collaborative research project explored how bio-inspired wing structural compliance impacts the development of the LEV flow structure above a wing, and in turn, how that fluid-structure interaction affects the forces that are generated. 

 

During this project, our team created and used efficient, lower-fidelity computer models to investigate how wing stiffness relates to differences in aerodynamics performance. The computational models that we developed simultaneously modeled the aerodynamics of the flow and the structural deformation of the wing. The primary computational tool was a 2-Dimensional model used to examine an array of different leading-edge and chordwise stiffnesses (i.e., from the front to back of the wing). The computational models were compared with the water tank experiments performed by our collaborators during this project and showed good trend agreement for early stages of the flow development.

 

Our computational studies found that wing flexibility appears to have an impact on aerodynamic force and LEV flow structure development. First, very flexible wing models showed lower total force production and shorter LEV presistence than comparable stiffer wing models. Second, flexibility appeared to provide the beneficial property of smoothing the force production when compared with similar rigid wings which tended to have more abrupt force transitions when the wing motion suddenly changed. Third, the flexible wing structure flexes as forces increase. Once the forces approached/reached/passed a peak force value, the wing structure started returning towards its undeformed shape. For some of the wings studied, this strucural loading/unloading beneficially reduced the rate at which forces decay after the maximum force was achieved. Fourth, in some cases, certain stiff (but not completely rigid) wing models appeared to have the beneficial property of improving the persistence of the LEV above the wing.
